text: Is Anyones HubSpot RSS Feed all of a sudden not pulling everything through?

Hi there! From your experience, do u think HubSpot CMS is still relevant to build a non-merchant product catalog website with about 100 products ? (I’m a bit afraid of the catalog administration regarding the lack of treeview and the possible complexity to build a faceted navigation).
as far I can see I would definitely use HubDB for that project. That will generate dynamically all the product pages
Given the volume, I agree with you on this point! I need to have a deeper look to faceting nav development in HubSpot now, and I will have my answer :wink: Thx Gonzalo!
<@U4F0XJWGM> if you're building out your product tree in HubDB don't be afraid to utilize the category trees in HubDB to create your menu structure that you would need.
<@U25C65C3S> thx for the advice :+1:
Thanks <@U22PJPGK0>
A file, which can't be shown because your team is past the free storage limit, was commented on.
A file, which can't be shown because your team is past the free storage limit, was commented on.
Found it

Hey Chad, not 100% sure, at best guess I'd say it's because these are not delivered the same way a JS file is through Design Manager, but it may also be because those files are quite old. I've passed this on to my team, I'll follow up when I know more :+1:
ok. Those shouldn’t be old files . They are from a new site that we are using a few ctas on.
Here is a little thing that has been bugging me. Say I use tab to indent my lines like a sane person. That would look like this:

Hi all. this is my first post. I am have been struggling with my mobile menu for a couple of day. it turns out to be this little piece of code that was in the boilerplate. what is the purpose? can i delete?
<@UB380RRMM> uploaded a file: <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/files/UB380RRMM/FB33Z31QW/image.png|image.png>

that bit of css seems to prevent my hamburger from aligning properly, it always shows up too low. <https://preview.hs-sites.com/_hcms/preview/template/multi?blog_listing=true&content_group_id=null&is_buffered_template_layout=true&portalId=518490&tc_deviceCategory=undefined&template_layout_id=5832075048&updated=1528217597583>
Looks like that would be fine
So what is happening is if you have an absolutely positioned element inside of a relatively positioned element it will still be constrained to that element.
<@UB380RRMM> But if you take that off you’re going to want to add ```top:10px;``` to your .mobile-trigger element.
didn’t even know they included an auto indent feature! O_O  but I 100% agree, same number of spaces would be really nice.
hey HS peeps I am having an interesting situation i could use some insight
Im using the menu module syntax to export to template variable
how do i display the menu this way? I tried "{{ widget_data.mega_menu }}" but this just outputs the object of the widget
<@U504BHZ6K> uploaded a file: <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/files/U504BHZ6K/FB1HM5AE4/-.txt|Untitled>
All i want to do is output the menu with just <ul> and <li> and <a>
<@U22PNRAJD> <@U22PWJ41G> :point_up:
does the beta design manager not have custom HTML or custom HubL?

Just took a look to confirm, but my understanding is that menus don't store data in the way you'd imagine; they don't have attributes like "parent" "child" etc with all your items from the UI (not saying they shouldn't, just that they don't right now)

so looking at the developer info, the available fields in the menu module object under widget data are "site_map_name," "root_type," "parent_widget_container," "label," "export_to_template_context," "flow," and "overrideable"

You can download the custom HTML module from the template marketplace, but the general consensus is that devs should move to using Modules for use cases where we would previously use custom HTML or HubL modules.
so widget variable on menu isnt viable?
any dowsides to removing the min-height from .row-fluid [class*="span"]

In general it's a bit of a pain to do something like you're saying with the menu modules. It's possible, but can take some "creativity." I think there are some blog posts floating around however. If you're not set on using the menu UI, you could always use a HubDB table. That would offer you some more flexibility.

It seems like even <http://HubSpot.com|HubSpot.com> is using HubDB tables for menu structure - I was digging around today and the page itself is built (what seems like) almost entirely on language / country-based HubDB queries to generate internal links
thanks Mark
i was hoping i could just grab the source of the menu and replace or strip out what i dont want
Interesting...
<@U7UBMQMDK> may be able to help ^^

No problem Russell, I know it feels like it should just work the way you're describing. I did find one of the blogs I was thinking of, and if you look at the comments, one workaround to still _kinda_ integrate the menus UI is to have the child drop menus configured as individual advanced menus
its a static menu we need integration with the advanced menu editor
YEah - check it out: <https://api.hubapi.com/hubdb/api/v2/tables/680621/rows?portalId=53&orderBy=name>

Yeah, adding the ability to easily extend or reference menu data in the module / template context is something we’ve definitely chatted about here at HS in the past. I definitely see the use-case for it-- but it’s not something we expose in the HubL context at this time. HubDB’s is a potentially decent workaround for that, but I’d like to see us expose more of the menu data contextually in the future (whether that’s in JSON, the full source… tbd).
gotcha thanks Kevin
